importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the Capitol attack during which Christopher Moynihan participated by rummaging through a senator's notebook and taking photos.
Date of the arrest and subsequent legal developments involving Moynihan, including the threat against Hakeem Jeffries and the hearing on terroristic threat charges.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the January 6, 2021 Capitol attack to 2025 captures the timeline of Moynihan’s conviction, pardon, and renewed legal threat, highlighting ongoing political tensions and public safety concerns.

keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former January 6 Capitol rioter, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the Capitol attack.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier this year as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.
Moynihan made a threatening text message stating he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and claimed he would eliminate a 'terrorist' in New York City.
A New York judge ruled that Moynihan remains in prison pending a hearing on whether he can be released on bail for the terroristic threat charge.
Moynihan has a history of opiate addiction and prior drug-related convictions, and his attorneys requested mental health and substance abuse treatment during sentencing.
Law enforcement is concerned about increasing threats against public officials, especially after recent high-profile assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk.
Hakeem Jeffries criticized Trump’s blanket pardon, emphasizing that threats of violence will not stop democratic participation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, citing a text message stating he would kill Jeffries 'for the future.' Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier this year, Moynihan remains in prison pending a hearing on a terroristic threat charge. His prior conviction stemmed from obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct at the Capitol. Law enforcement has expressed concern over threats against public figures, especially after the recent assassination of Charlie Kirk. Moynihan has a history of opiate addiction and prior drug-related offenses, and his attorneys requested mental health and substance abuse treatment during sentencing. The incident underscores ongoing political tensions, public safety concerns, and the broader implications of executive pardons in the aftermath of large-scale civil unrest.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
